title: Overhaul Spack's URL parsing
body:
Fixes #2946.
Fixes #2947.
Fixes #3176.
Fixes #3554.

I plan on overhauling Spack's URL parsing so that we more often correctly guess the name and version of a package from its URL. In order to do this, I need an accurate baseline of URLs that I can try to match with regexes. The goal of this PR is to ensure that every URL in Spack:

1. Is a "real" URL for a download tarball, not just the URL of the homepage

A lot of packages look like:
```python
homepage = "https://github.com/google/cityhash"
url      = "https://github.com/google/cityhash"
```
This is a "fake" URL. It cannot be used to download the package. In fact, it can't be used for anything, so I removed it.

2. Is for a version that exists in the Spack package, not a random version

For example, autotools has a URL:
```python
url      = 'http://ftp.gnu.org/gnu/automake/automake-1.14.tar.gz'
```
but that version isn't in the package. There is no way to ensure that `1.14` is being correctly parsed as a version number unless that version is in the package.

3. Can theoretically be parsed to find the name and version of the package

Some URLs are not versioned, like:
```python
url      = "ftp://ftp.pmel.noaa.gov/ferret/pub/source/fer_source.tar.gz"
```
Use a versioned URL where possible:
```python
url      = "ftp://ftp.pmel.noaa.gov/ferret/pub/source/fer_source.v696.tar.gz"
```
Also, some URLs contain a commit tag instead of a version number:
```python
version('1.9.5.1.1', 'd035e4bc704d136db79b43ab371b27d2',
        url='https://www.github.com/jswhit/pyproj/tarball/0be612cc9f972e38b50a90c946a9b353e2ab140f')
```
This is a valid URL, but there is no way we could possibly extract the version number from that. Spack has support for checking out a particular commit, so use it:
```python
version('1.9.5.1.1', git='https://www.github.com/jswhit/pyproj.git',
        commit='0be612cc9f972e38b50a90c946a9b353e2ab140f')
```
How much of a difference does this make? Before this PR, our performance was:
```
$ spack url test
==> Generating a summary of URL parsing in Spack...

    Total URLs found:          1171
    Names correctly parsed:    1050/1171 (89.67%)
    Versions correctly parsed: 1074/1171 (91.72%)
```
Of course, this isn't accurate due to all of the fake URLs. After this PR, we can see that our real performance is:
```
$ spack url test
==> Generating a summary of URL parsing in Spack...

    Total URLs found:          1151
    Names correctly parsed:    1038/1151 (90.18%)
    Versions correctly parsed: 1089/1151 (94.61%)
```
Much better.

@citibeth You may want to check this out. A couple of these packages are yours, so I want to make sure you're okay with the changes. I made sure that all of the packages I've modified can still be fetched and that the checksum in the package is correct.
